metadata.purpose: ESG assessment frameworks and scoring methodologies for infrastructure finance

esg_frameworks.name: GRI Standards
esg_frameworks.description: The world's most widely used sustainability reporting system providing common global language to assess and report environmental, social and economic impacts. Used by 78% of the world's biggest 250 companies by revenue.

tiers.name: Universal Standards
tiers.description: Apply to all organizations, incorporate reporting on human rights and environmental due diligence

tiers.name: Topic Standards
tiers.description: Address disclosures relevant to particular topics across environmental, social, and economic dimensions

tiers.name: Sector Standards
tiers.description: Enable more consistent reporting on sector-specific impacts including Oil & Gas, Coal, Mining, Agriculture

metrics: Total fuel and electricity consumed within organizational boundaries
Energy intensity ratio (e.g., gigajoules per tonne)
Reductions in energy consumption from efficiency projects
Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
Total water discharge by destination and quality parameters
environmental.update: 2018 revision focuses on water stress and basin context

metrics: Operational sites in or adjacent to protected areas
IUCN Red List species affected by operations
Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
Waste generated by type and disposal method
Materials used by weight or volume
Occupational health and safety management system
Worker training on occupational health and safety
Workers covered by an occupational health and safety management system
Average hours of training per employee
Programs for skills management and lifelong learning
Diversity of governance bodies and employees
Ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men
Operations screened for human rights risks
Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions
Operations with significant actual or potential negative impacts on local communities
Tax governance, control, and risk management

esg_frameworks.reporting_approach: Organizations report on their most significant impacts using relevant topic standards
esg_frameworks.scoring_methodology: No official GRI scoring system; framework focuses on disclosure quality and completeness
updates_2024: Mining sector standards published (February 2024, effective January 2026)
Climate change review ongoing for GRI 302 (Energy) and GRI 305 (Emissions)
esg_frameworks.adoption_rate: 78% of world's largest 250 companies, 68% of top 100 businesses in 58 countries
esg_frameworks.infrastructure_relevance: High - applicable through universal standards and developing sector-specific guidance

esg_frameworks.name: SASB Standards
esg_frameworks.focus: Financial Materiality and Industry-Specific ESG Disclosure
esg_frameworks.description: Industry-based disclosure standards identifying the subset of sustainability issues most relevant to financial performance in each of 77 industries. Now maintained by the IFRS Foundation's International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB).

leadership_governance: Management of the Legal & Regulatory Environment

industries.name: Engineering & Construction Services
industries.description: Provides engineering, construction, design, consulting services for building and infrastructure projects including power plants, dams, pipelines, highways, bridges, tunnels, railways, ports, airports, water networks
key_issues: Lifecycle Impacts of Buildings and Infrastructure
Climate Impacts on Project Planning & Design
critical_metrics: Defect rate and associated corrective actions
Discussion of processes to assess and manage risks and opportunities associated with designing sustainable buildings and infrastructure
Amount of backlog for non-residential, non-fossil fuel-related projects
Total amount of monetary losses from legal proceedings associated with defects

industries.name: Water Utilities & Services
key_issues: Network Resiliency & Impacts of Climate Change

industries.name: Commercial Banks
key_issues: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis

industries.name: Investment Banking & Brokerage
key_issues: Integration of ESG Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities

industries.name: Asset Management & Custody Activities
key_issues: Integration of ESG Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Incorporation of ESG Factors in Portfolio Companies

esg_frameworks.reporting_approach: Companies report on financially material sustainability topics specific to their industry using quantitative metrics
esg_frameworks.scoring_methodology: No official SASB scoring system; framework emphasizes disclosure of decision-useful information for investors

tools.name: Materiality Finder
tools.description: Visual portfolio assessment tool showing exposure to specific sustainability risks across 26 general issue categories

tools.name: SASB Standards Taxonomy
tools.description: XBRL classification system for digital reporting

esg_frameworks.integration_status: Integrated into ISSB's IFRS S1 and S2 standards (2022-2024)
esg_frameworks.adoption_rate: 1.3M+ downloads across 170 countries, $80 trillion in investor assets supporting implementation
esg_frameworks.infrastructure_finance_relevance: Very High - specific standards for infrastructure sectors and financial institutions providing infrastructure finance
updates_2024: Recommended full adoption alongside ISSB's IFRS S1 and S2 standards
Ongoing priority reviews of SASB Standards by ISSB
Enhanced integration with global sustainability reporting framework

esg_frameworks.name: TCFD Recommendations
esg_frameworks.full_name: Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures
esg_frameworks.description: Framework developed by the Financial Stability Board to help public companies and other organizations disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through standardized, decision-useful information for investors, lenders, and insurance underwriters.

four_pillars.description: The organization's governance around climate-related risks and opportunities
recommended_disclosures: Describe the board's oversight of climate-related risks and opportunities
Describe management's role in assessing and managing climate-related risks and opportunities

four_pillars.description: The actual and potential impacts of climate-related risks and opportunities on the organization's businesses, strategy, and financial planning
recommended_disclosures: Describe the climate-related risks and opportunities the organization has identified over the short, medium, and long term
Describe the impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on the organization's businesses, strategy, and financial planning
Describe the resilience of the organization's strategy, taking into consideration different climate-related scenarios, including a 2°C or lower scenario
four_pillars.time_horizons: Short, medium, and long term (definitions vary by sector and asset lifecycles)

four_pillars.description: The processes used by the organization to identify, assess, and manage climate-related risks
recommended_disclosures: Describe the organization's processes for identifying and assessing climate-related risks
Describe the organization's processes for managing climate-related risks
Describe how processes for identifying, assessing, and managing climate-related risks are integrated into the organization's overall risk management

four_pillars.description: The metrics and targets used to assess and manage relevant climate-related risks and opportunities
recommended_disclosures: Disclose the metrics used by the organization to assess climate-related risks and opportunities in line with its strategy and risk management process
Disclose Scope 1, Scope 2, and, if appropriate, Scope 3 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, and the related risks
Describe the targets used by the organization to manage climate-related risks and opportunities and performance against targets

metrics: Scope 1 GHG emissions (direct emissions from owned or controlled sources)
Scope 2 GHG emissions (indirect emissions from purchased energy)
Scope 3 GHG emissions (all other indirect emissions in value chain)
key_metrics.note: Scope 3 disclosure recommended if appropriate for the organization

subtypes: Acute risks (extreme weather events: floods, storms, wildfires)
Chronic risks (gradual climate changes: temperature rise, sea level rise, water stress)

examples: Water usage targets in water-stressed areas

scenario_analysis.description: Organizations should describe the resilience of their strategy under different climate scenarios
recommended_scenarios: Other relevant scenarios based on organization's circumstances
scenario_analysis.infrastructure_consideration: Time horizons and scenario parameters should reflect long-lived asset lifecycles

applicable_sectors: All sectors with particular guidance for:

infrastructure_relevance.rationale: Infrastructure assets are long-lived and exposed to both physical climate risks (extreme weather, sea level rise) and transition risks (policy changes, technology shifts)
key_considerations: Long asset lifespans require long-term climate scenario analysis
Physical climate impacts on infrastructure location and design
Transition risk from low-carbon economy affecting fossil fuel infrastructure
Opportunities in climate-resilient and low-carbon infrastructure development

banks: GHG emissions associated with lending and other financial intermediary business activities (financed emissions)
asset_managers_owners: Weighted average carbon intensity of portfolios
Climate-related risks and opportunities in investment decisions
Engagement with investee companies on climate issues
insurance: Exposure to climate-related risks in underwriting portfolios
Climate-related risks and opportunities in investment portfolios

esg_frameworks.reporting_approach: Voluntary disclosure framework encouraging consistent, comparable, reliable, and clear climate-related financial information
esg_frameworks.scoring_methodology: No official scoring system; framework focuses on transparency and quality of climate-related financial disclosures
esg_frameworks.integration_status: Being incorporated into mandatory reporting requirements in multiple jurisdictions (UK, EU, New Zealand, others); forms basis for ISSB's IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures
esg_frameworks.adoption_rate: Supported by over 4,000 organizations globally; increasingly becoming mandatory in major economies
updates_2024: TCFD framework integrated into IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures (ISSB)
Enhanced guidance on Scope 3 emissions and financed emissions

esg_frameworks.name: CDP
esg_frameworks.description: The world's only independent environmental disclosure system enabling organizations to measure, disclose, and manage environmental data across climate, water, forests, and plastics. Operates a global disclosure system for investors, companies, cities, states and regions to manage their environmental impacts.

metrics: Scope 2 emissions (indirect emissions from purchased electricity, heat, cooling)
Scope 3 emissions (all other indirect emissions in value chain)
climate_change.note: Supply chain Scope 3 emissions average 26 times greater than operational emissions

climate_change.impact: Within two years of investor request, companies reduce direct emissions by 7-10% on average

scoring_methodology.score_range: A to F (with A being leadership level)

score_levels.name: Leadership
score_levels.description: Implementing current best practices, taking coordinated action on climate issues
score_levels.achievement_rate_2024: 2% of scored companies achieved A grade

score_levels.name: Management
score_levels.description: Taking coordinated action on climate issues

score_levels.name: Awareness
score_levels.description: Knowledge of climate issues and their impact on business

score_levels.name: Failure to Disclose
score_levels.description: Failed to provide sufficient information for CDP to evaluate performance

assessment_dimensions: Progress towards environmental action and targets
scoring_methodology.scoring_process: Simplifies hundreds of datapoints within each response into a metric for financial decision-making
essential_criteria_2024: Setting targets for emissions reductions (Climate Change)
Governance structure for climate issues (Climate Change)
Reporting on dependencies, impacts, risks, and opportunities (All themes)
Leadership-level criteria for A-List achievement (All themes)

2024_scoring_updates.climate_change: Essential criteria introduced across scoring levels for verification, targets, governance, and DIRO (dependencies, impacts, risks, opportunities)
2024_scoring_updates.water_security: Financial services sector scored for first time; essential criteria introduced at Leadership and A-List levels
2024_scoring_updates.forests: Single forest score replacing separate commodity scores; essential criteria for Leadership level introduced
2024_scoring_updates.new_checks: New A-list checks reflecting need for transformational, urgent and collaborative change

applicable_sectors: Financial Services (including banks, asset managers, insurance)

application: Infrastructure companies disclose direct environmental impacts
Financial institutions report financed emissions from infrastructure portfolios
Supply chain engagement across infrastructure value chains
Climate risk assessment for long-lived infrastructure assets
financial_services_metrics: Financed emissions from lending and investment portfolios
Integration of climate considerations in financing decisions
Engagement with portfolio companies on climate action

esg_frameworks.reporting_approach: Companies respond to detailed annual questionnaires; responses are scored by CDP or accredited scoring partners
market_impact: CDP A List companies outperformed market peers by average 6% in stock gains over last decade
Supply chain members achieved $54.4bn in savings from emissions reduction
Within two years of investor request, companies reduce direct emissions by 7-10%

adoption_2024.disclosure_requests: Investor requests and supply chain engagement drive disclosures

scope.scope: Financially material ESG issues by industry
Environmental performance and disclosure (climate, water, forests)
scope.audience: Investors, supply chain partners, environmental stakeholders

infrastructure_finance_application.GRI: Universal application with sector-specific guidance emerging; comprehensive sustainability reporting
infrastructure_finance_application.SASB: Highly specific with 8 infrastructure industry standards covering financial materiality
infrastructure_finance_application.TCFD: Critical for long-lived infrastructure assets exposed to climate risks; scenario analysis essential
infrastructure_finance_application.CDP: Direct measurement and benchmarking of environmental performance; investor-driven disclosure

complementarity: GRI and SASB can be used together (GRI for stakeholder reporting, SASB for investor reporting)
TCFD aligns with all frameworks for climate-specific disclosures
CDP questionnaires incorporate TCFD recommendations and reference GRI/SASB standards
ISSB standards (IFRS S1/S2) build on SASB and TCFD creating unified global baseline
convergence_trends_2024: ISSB consolidation: SASB and TCFD integrated into IFRS S1 (General Sustainability) and S2 (Climate)
Increasing mandatory adoption of TCFD recommendations globally
GRI and ISSB standards designed for dual reporting (impact and financial materiality)
CDP aligning questionnaires with ISSB standards and TCFD recommendations

minimum_framework_set: SASB Standards for industry-specific material issues (Infrastructure and Financials sectors)
TCFD Recommendations for climate-related financial risks
CDP Climate Change for measurement, disclosure, and benchmarking
comprehensive_approach: GRI Standards for comprehensive sustainability reporting to all stakeholders
SASB Standards for financially material industry-specific metrics
TCFD Recommendations for detailed climate risk analysis and scenario planning
CDP Disclosure for environmental performance measurement and external validation
key_considerations_for_infrastructure_fi: Long asset lifecycles require long-term climate scenario analysis (TCFD)
Physical climate risks to infrastructure location and operations (TCFD, CDP)
Transition risks from policy changes and technology shifts (TCFD, SASB)
Financed emissions and portfolio climate risk for financial institutions (SASB Financials, CDP)
Supply chain Scope 3 emissions often dwarf operational emissions (CDP, GRI)
Social impacts including community engagement and worker safety (GRI, SASB)
Governance structures for ESG risk management (all frameworks)
